Dim.def: Not bright or distinct; wanting luminousness or clearness; obscure in luster or sound; dusky; darkish; obscure; indistinct; overcast; tarnished.
Of obscure vision; not seeing clearly; hence, dull of apprehension; of weak perception; obtuse.
To render dim, obscure, or dark; to make less bright or distinct; to take away the luster of; to darken; to dull; to obscure; to eclipse.
To deprive of distinct vision; to hinder from seeing clearly, either by dazzling or clouding the eyes; to darken the senses or understanding of.

Dime.def: A silver coin of the United States, of the value of ten cents; the tenth of a dollar.

Dimension.def: Measure in a single line, as length, breadth, height, thickness, or circumference; extension; measurement; -- usually, in the plural, measure in length and breadth, or in length, breadth, and thickness; extent; size; as, the dimensions of a room, or of a ship; the dimensions of a farm, of a kingdom.
Extent; reach; scope; importance; as, a project of large dimensions.
The degree of manifoldness of a quantity; as, time is quantity having one dimension; volume has three dimensions, relative to extension.

A literal factor, as numbered in characterizing a term. The term dimensions forms with the cardinal numbers a phrase equivalent to degree with the ordinal; thus, a2b2c is a term of five dimensions, or of the fifth degree.
The manifoldness with which the fundamental units of time, length, and mass are involved in determining the units of other physical quantities.

Dimensionless.def: Without dimensions; having no appreciable or noteworthy extent.

Dimensive.def: Without dimensions; marking dimensions or the limits.

Dimera.def: A division of Coleoptera, having two joints to the tarsi.
A division of the Hemiptera, including the aphids.

Dimerous.def: Composed of, or having, two parts of each kind.

Dimeter.def: Having two poetical measures or meters.

Dimethyl.def: Ethane; -- sometimes so called because regarded as consisting of two methyl radicals. See Ethane.

Dimidiate.def: Divided into two equal parts; reduced to half in shape or form.
Consisting of only one half of what the normal condition requires; having the appearance of lacking one half; as, a dimidiate leaf, which has only one side developed.
Having the organs of one side, or half, different in function from the corresponding organs on the other side; as, dimidiate hermaphroditism.
To divide into two equal parts.
To represent the half of; to halve.

Dimidiation.def: The act of dimidiating or halving; the state of being dimidiate.

Diminish.def: To make smaller in any manner; to reduce in bulk or amount; to lessen; -- opposed to augment or increase.
To lessen the authority or dignity of; to put down; to degrade; to abase; to weaken.
To make smaller by a half step; to make (an interval) less than minor; as, a diminished seventh.
To become or appear less or smaller; to lessen; as, the apparent size of an object diminishes as we recede from it.

Diminishable.def: Capable of being diminished or lessened.

Diminisher.def: One who, or that which, diminishes anything.

Diminuendo.def: In a gradually diminishing manner; with abatement of tone; decrescendo; -- expressed on the staff by Dim., or Dimin., or the sign.

Diminution.def: The act of diminishing, or of making or becoming less; state of being diminished; reduction in size, quantity, or degree; -- opposed to augmentation or increase.
The act of lessening dignity or consideration, or the state of being deprived of dignity; a lowering in estimation; degradation; abasement.
Omission, inaccuracy, or defect in a record.
In counterpoint, the imitation of, or reply to, a subject, in notes of half the length or value of those the subject itself.

Diminutive.def: Below the average size; very small; little.
Expressing diminution; as, a diminutive word.
Something of very small size or value; an insignificant thing.
A derivative from a noun, denoting a small or a young object of the same kind with that denoted by the primitive; as, gosling, eaglet, lambkin.

Diminutiveness.def: The quality of being diminutive; smallness; littleness; minuteness.

Dimissory.def: Sending away; dismissing to another jurisdiction; granting leave to depart.

Dimit.def: To dismiss, let go, or release.

Dimity.def: A cotton fabric employed for hangings and furniture coverings, and formerly used for women's under-garments. It is of many patterns, both plain and twilled, and occasionally is printed in colors.

Dimly.def: In a dim or obscure manner; not brightly or clearly; with imperfect sight.

Dimness.def: The state or quality / being dim; lack of brightness, clearness, or distinctness; dullness; obscurity.
Dullness, or want of clearness, of vision or of intellectual perception.

Dimorph.def: Either one of the two forms of a dimorphous substance; as, calcite and aragonite are dimorphs.

Dimorphic.def: Having the property of dimorphism; dimorphous.

Dimorphism.def: Difference of form between members of the same species, as when a plant has two kinds of flowers, both hermaphrodite (as in the partridge berry), or when there are two forms of one or both sexes of the same species of butterfly.
Crystallization in two independent forms of the same chemical compound, as of calcium carbonate as calcite and aragonite.

Dimorphous.def: Characterized by dimorphism; occurring under two distinct forms, not dependent on sex; dimorphic.
Crystallizing under two forms fundamentally different, while having the same chemical composition.

Dimple.def: A slight natural depression or indentation on the surface of some part of the body, esp. on the cheek or chin.
A slight indentation on any surface.
To form dimples; to sink into depressions or little inequalities.
To mark with dimples or dimplelike depressions.

Dimplement.def: The state of being dimpled, or marked with gentle depressions.

Dimply.def: Full of dimples, or small depressions; dimpled; as, the dimply pool.

Dimyaria.def: An order of lamellibranchiate mollusks having an anterior and posterior adductor muscle, as the common clam. See Bivalve.

Dimyarian.def: Like or pertaining to the Dimya.

Din.def: Loud, confused, harsh noise; a loud, continuous, rattling or clanging sound; clamor; roar.
To strike with confused or clanging sound; to stun with loud and continued noise; to harass with clamor; as, to din the ears with cries.
To utter with a din; to repeat noisily; to ding.
To sound with a din; a ding.

Dinaphthyl.def: A colorless, crystalline hydrocarbon, C20H14, obtained from naphthylene, and consisting of a doubled naphthylene radical.

Dinar.def: A petty money of accounts of Persia.
An ancient gold coin of the East.

Dine.def: To eat the principal regular meal of the day; to take dinner.
To give a dinner to; to furnish with the chief meal; to feed; as, to dine a hundred men.
To dine upon; to have to eat.

Diner-out.def: One who often takes his dinner away from home, or in company.

Ding.def: To cause to sound or ring.
To strike; to thump; to pound.
To sound, as a bell; to ring; to clang.
To talk with vehemence, importunity, or reiteration; to bluster.
A thump or stroke, especially of a bell.

Dingdong.def: The sound of, or as of, repeated strokes on a metallic body, as a bell; a repeated and monotonous sound.
An attachment to a clock by which the quarter hours are struck upon bells of different tones.

Dinghy.def: A kind of boat used in the East Indies.

Dinginess.def: Quality of being dingy; a dusky hue.

Dingle.def: A narrow dale; a small dell; a small, secluded, and embowered valley.

Dingo.def: A wild dog found in Australia, but supposed to have introduced at a very early period. It has a wolflike face, bushy tail, and a reddish brown color.

Dingy.def: Soiled; sullied; of a dark or dusky color; dark brown; dirty.

Dinichthys.def: A genus of large extinct Devonian ganoid fishes. In some parts of Ohio remains of the Dinichthys are abundant, indicating animals twenty feet in length.

Dink.def: To deck; -- often with out or up.

Dinmont.def: A wether sheep between one and two years old.

Dinner.def: The principal meal of the day, eaten by most people about midday, but by many (especially in cities) at a later hour.

Dinoceras.def: A genus of large extinct Eocene mammals from Wyoming; -- called also Uintatherium. See Illustration in Appendix.

Dinornis.def: A genus of extinct, ostrichlike birds of gigantic size, which formerly inhabited New Zealand. See Moa.

Dinosauria.def: An order of extinct mesozoic reptiles, mostly of large size (whence the name). Notwithstanding their size, they present birdlike characters in the skeleton, esp. in the pelvis and hind limbs. Some walked on their three-toed hind feet, thus producing the large "bird tracks," so-called, of mesozoic sandstones; others were five-toed and quadrupedal. See Illust. of Compsognathus, also Illustration of Dinosaur in Appendix.

Dinotherium.def: A large extinct proboscidean mammal from the miocene beds of Europe and Asia. It is remarkable fora pair of tusks directed downward from the decurved apex of the lower jaw.

Dint.def: The mark left by a blow; an indentation or impression made by violence; a dent.
Force; power; -- esp. in the phrase by dint of.
To make a mark or cavity on or in, by a blow or by pressure; to dent.

Diocesan.def: Of or pertaining to a diocese; as, diocesan missions.
A bishop, viewed in relation to his diocese; as, the diocesan of New York.
The clergy or the people of a diocese.

Diocese.def: The circuit or extent of a bishop's jurisdiction; the district in which a bishop exercises his ecclesiastical authority.

Diocesener.def: One who belongs to a diocese.

Diodon.def: A genus of spinose, plectognath fishes, having the teeth of each jaw united into a single beaklike plate. They are able to inflate the body by taking in air or water, and, hence, are called globefishes, swellfishes, etc. Called also porcupine fishes, and sea hedgehogs.

Diodont.def: Like or pertaining to the genus Diodon.
A fish of the genus Diodon, or an allied genus.

Dioecia.def: A Linnaean class of plants having the stamens and pistils on different plants.
A subclass of gastropod mollusks in which the sexes are separate. It includes most of the large marine species, like the conchs, cones, and cowries.

Dioecious.def: Having the sexes in two separate individuals; -- applied to plants in which the female flowers occur on one individual and the male flowers on another of the same species, and to animals in which the ovum is produced by one individual and the sperm cell by another; -- opposed to monoecious.

Dioeciousness.def: The state or quality of being dioecious.

Diogenes.def: A Greek Cynic philosopher (412?-323 B. C.) who lived much in Athens and was distinguished for contempt of the common aims and conditions of life, and for sharp, caustic sayings.

Diomedea.def: A genus of large sea birds, including the albatross. See Albatross.

Dionaea.def: An insectivorous plant. See Venus's flytrap.

Dionysian.def: Relating to Dionysius, a monk of the 6th century; as, the Dionysian, or Christian, era.

Diophantine.def: Originated or taught by Diophantus, the Greek writer on algebra.

Diopside.def: A crystallized variety of pyroxene, of a clear, grayish green color; mussite.

Dioptase.def: A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring in emerald-green crystals.

Dioptra.def: An optical instrument, invented by Hipparchus, for taking altitudes, leveling, etc.

Dioptre.def: A unit employed by oculists in numbering glasses according to the metric system; a refractive power equal to that of a glass whose principal focal distance is one meter.

Dioptric.def: Of or pertaining to the dioptre, or to the metric system of numbering glasses.

Dioptrical.def: Of or pertaining to dioptrics; assisting vision by means of the refraction of light; refractive; as, the dioptric system; a dioptric glass or telescope.

Dioptrics.def: The science of the refraction of light; that part of geometrical optics which treats of the laws of the refraction of light in passing from one medium into another, or through different mediums, as air, water, or glass, and esp. through different lenses; -- distinguished from catoptrics, which refers to reflected light.

Diorama.def: A mode of scenic representation, invented by Daguerre and Bouton, in which a painting is seen from a distance through a large opening. By a combination of transparent and opaque painting, and of transmitted and reflected light, and by contrivances such as screens and shutters, much diversity of scenic effect is produced.
A building used for such an exhibition.

Diorite.def: An igneous, crystalline in structure, consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar and hornblende. It includes part of what was called greenstone.

Diorthotic.def: Relating to the correcting or straightening out of something; corrective.

Dioscorea.def: A genus of plants. See Yam.

Diota.def: A vase or drinking cup having two handles or ears.

Dioxide.def: An oxide containing two atoms of oxygen in each molecule; binoxide.
An oxide containing but one atom or equivalent of oxygen to two of a metal; a suboxide.

Dioxindol.def: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance obtained by the reduction of isatin. It is a member of the indol series; -- hence its name.

Dip.def: To plunge or immerse; especially, to put for a moment into a liquid; to insert into a fluid and withdraw again.
To immerse for baptism; to baptize by immersion.
To wet, as if by immersing; to moisten.
To plunge or engage thoroughly in any affair.
To take out, by dipping a dipper, ladle, or other receptacle, into a fluid and removing a part; -- often with out; as, to dip water from a boiler; to dip out water.
To engage as a pledge; to mortgage.
To immerse one's self; to become plunged in a liquid; to sink.
To perform the action of plunging some receptacle, as a dipper, ladle. etc.; into a liquid or a soft substance and removing a part.
To pierce; to penetrate; -- followed by in or into.
To enter slightly or cursorily; to engage one's self desultorily or by the way; to partake limitedly; -- followed by in or into.
To incline downward from the plane of the horizon; as, strata of rock dip.
The action of dipping or plunging for a moment into a liquid.
Inclination downward; direction below a horizontal line; slope; pitch.
A liquid, as a sauce or gravy, served at table with a ladle or spoon.

Diphenyl.def: A white crystalline substance, C6H5.C6H5, obtained by leading benzene through a heated iron tube. It consists of two benzene or phenyl radicals united.

Diphtheria.def: A very dangerous contagious disease in which the air passages, and especially the throat, become coated with a false membrane, produced by the solidification of an inflammatory exudation.  Cf. Group.

Diphtheritic.def: Pertaining to, or connected with, diphtheria.
Having characteristics resembling those of diphtheria; as, diphtheritic inflammation of the bladder.

Diphthong.def: A coalition or union of two vowel sounds pronounced in one syllable; as, ou in out, oi in noise; -- called a proper diphthong.
A vowel digraph; a union of two vowels in the same syllable, only one of them being sounded; as, ai in rain, eo in people; -- called an improper diphthong.
To form or pronounce as a diphthong; diphthongize.

Diphthongal.def: Relating or belonging to a diphthong; having the nature of a diphthong.

Diphthongalize.def: To make into a diphthong; to pronounce as a diphthong.

Diphthongic.def: Of the nature of diphthong; diphthongal.

Diphthongization.def: The act of changing into a diphthong.

Diphthongize.def: To change into a diphthong, as by affixing another vowel to a simple vowel.

Diphycercal.def: Having the tail fin divided into two equal parts by the notochord, or end of the vertebral column; protocercal. See Protocercal.

Diphygenic.def: Having two modes of embryonic development.

Diphyllous.def: Having two leaves, as a calyx, etc.

Diphyodont.def: Having two successive sets of teeth (deciduous and permanent), one succeeding the other; as, a diphyodont mammal; diphyodont dentition; -- opposed to monophyodont.
An animal having two successive sets of teeth.

Diphyozooid.def: One of the free-swimming sexual zooids of Siphonophora.

Diplanar.def: Of or pertaining to two planes.

Dipleidoscope.def: An instrument for determining the time of apparent noon. It consists of two mirrors and a plane glass disposed in the form of a prism, so that, by the reflections of the sun's rays from their surfaces, two images are presented to the eye, moving in opposite directions, and coinciding at the instant the sun's center is on the meridian.

Diploblastic.def: Characterizing the ovum when it has two primary germinal layers.

Diplocardiac.def: Having the heart completely divided or double, one side systemic, the other pulmonary.

Diplococcus.def: A form of micrococcus in which cocci are united in a binary manner. See Micrococcus.

Diploe.def: The soft, spongy, or cancellated substance between the plates of the skull.

Diplogenic.def: Partaking of the nature of two bodies; producing two substances.

Diploic.def: Of or pertaining to the diploe.

Diploid.def: A solid bounded by twenty-four similar quadrilateral faces. It is a hemihedral form of the hexoctahedron.

Diploma.def: A letter or writing, usually under seal, conferring some privilege, honor, or power; a document bearing record of a degree conferred by a literary society or educational institution.

Diplomacy.def: The art and practice of conducting negotiations between nations (particularly in securing treaties), including the methods and forms usually employed.
Dexterity or skill in securing advantages; tact.
The body of ministers or envoys resident at a court; the diplomatic body.

Diplomate.def: To invest with a title o/ privilege by diploma.

Diplomatical.def: Pertaining to diplomacy; relating to the foreign ministers at a court, who are called the diplomatic body.
Characterized by tact and shrewdness; dexterous; artful; as, diplomatic management.

Diplomatic.def: A minister, official agent, or envoy to a foreign court; a diplomatist.

Diplomatically.def: According to the rules of diplomacy; in the manner of a diplomatist; artfully.

Diplomatic.def: The science of diplomas, or the art of deciphering ancient writings, and determining their age, authenticity, etc.; paleography.

Diplomatist.def: A person employed in, or skilled in, diplomacy; a diplomat.

Diplopy.def: The act or state of seeing double.

Diplopoda.def: An order of myriapods having two pairs of legs on each segment; the Chilognatha.

Diplostemonous.def: Having twice as many stamens as petals, as the geranium.

Dipneumona.def: A group of spiders having only two lunglike organs.

Dipnoi.def: A group of ganoid fishes, including the living genera Ceratodus and Lepidosiren, which present the closest approximation to the Amphibia. The air bladder acts as a lung, and the nostrils open inside the mouth. See Ceratodus, and Illustration in Appendix.

Dipody.def: Two metrical feet taken together, or included in one measure.

Dipolar.def: Having two poles, as a magnetic bar.

Dipper.def: One who, or that which, dips; especially, a vessel used to dip water or other liquid; a ladle.
The water ouzel (Cinolus aquaticus) of Europe.
The American dipper or ouzel (Cinclus Mexicanus).

Dipping.def: The act or process of immersing.
The act of lifting or moving a liquid with a dipper, ladle, or the like.
The process of cleaning or brightening sheet metal or metalware, esp. brass, by dipping it in acids, etc.
The practice of taking snuff by rubbing the teeth or gums with a stick or brush dipped in snuff.

Dipropargyl.def: A pungent, mobile, volatile liquid, C6H6, produced artificially from certain allyl derivatives. Though isomeric with benzine, it is very different in its chemical relations. Called also dipropinyl.

Dipropyl.def: One of the hexane paraffins, found in petroleum, consisting of two propyl radicals. See Hexane.

Diprotodon.def: An extinct Quaternary marsupial from Australia, about as large as the hippopotamus; -- so named because of its two large front teeth. See Illustration in Appendix.

Dipsas.def: A serpent whose bite was fabled to produce intense thirst.
A genus of harmless colubrine snakes.

Dipsomania.def: A morbid an uncontrollable craving (often periodic) for drink, esp. for alcoholic liquors; also improperly used to denote acute and chronic alcoholism.

Dipsomaniac.def: One who has an irrepressible desire for alcoholic drinks.

Diptera.def: An extensive order of insects having only two functional wings and two balancers, as the house fly, mosquito, etc. They have a suctorial proboscis, often including two pairs of sharp organs (mandibles and maxillae) with which they pierce the skin of animals. They undergo a complete metamorphosis, their larvae (called maggots) being usually without feet.

Dipteral.def: Having two wings only; belonging to the order Diptera.
Having a double row of columns on each on the flanks, as well as in front and rear; -- said of a temple.

Dipteran.def: An insect of the order Diptera.

Dipterocarpus.def: A genus of trees found in the East Indies, some species of which produce a fragrant resin, other species wood oil. The fruit has two long wings.

Dipterous.def: Having two wings, as certain insects; belonging to the order Diptera.

Dipterygian.def: Having two dorsal fins; -- said of certain fishes.

Diptote.def: A noun which has only two cases.

Diptych.def: A writing tablet consisting of two leaves of rigid material connected by hinges and shutting together so as to protect the writing within.
A picture or series of pictures painted on two tablets connected by hinges. See Triptych.
A double catalogue, containing in one part the names of living, and in the other of deceased, ecclesiastics and benefactors of the church; a catalogue of saints.

Dipyre.def: A mineral of the scapolite group; -- so called from the double effect of fire upon it, in fusing it, and   rendering it phosphorescent.

Dipyridine.def: A polymeric form of pyridine, C10H10N2, obtained as a colorless oil by the action of sodium on pyridine.

Dipyridil.def: A crystalline nitrogenous base, C10H8N2, obtained by the reduction of pyridine.

Diradiation.def: The emission and diffusion of rays of light.

Dire.def: Evil in great degree; dreadful; dismal; horrible; terrible; lamentable.

Direct.def: Straight; not crooked, oblique, or circuitous; leading by the short or shortest way to a point or end; as, a direct line; direct means.
Straightforward; not of crooked ways, or swerving from truth and openness; sincere; outspoken.
In the line of descent; not collateral; as, a descendant in the direct line.
In the direction of the general planetary motion, or from west to east; in the order of the signs; not retrograde; -- said of the motion of a celestial body.
To arrange in a direct or straight line, as against a mark, or towards a goal; to point; to aim; as, to direct an arrow or a piece of ordnance.
To point out or show to (any one), as the direct or right course or way; to guide, as by pointing out the way; as, he directed me to the left-hand road.

To determine the direction or course of; to cause to go on in a particular manner; to order in the way to a certain end; to regulate; to govern; as, to direct the affairs of a nation or the movements of an army.
To point out to with authority; to instruct as a superior; to order; as, he directed them to go.
To put a direction or address upon; to mark with the name and residence of the person to whom anything is sent; to superscribe; as, to direct a letter.
To give direction; to point out a course; to act as guide.
A character, thus [/], placed at the end of a staff on the line or space of the first note of the next staff, to apprise the performer of its situation.

Direct-acting.def: Acting directly, as one part upon another, without the intervention of other working parts.

Direction.def: The act of directing, of aiming, regulating, guiding, or ordering; guidance; management; superintendence; administration; as, the direction o/ public affairs or of a bank.
That which is imposed by directing; a guiding or authoritative instruction; prescription; order; command; as, he grave directions to the servants.
The name and residence of a person to whom any thing is sent, written upon the thing sent; superscription; address; as, the direction of a letter.

The line or course upon which anything is moving or aimed to move, or in which anything is lying or pointing; aim; line or point of tendency; direct line or course; as, the ship sailed in a southeasterly direction.
The body of managers of a corporation or enterprise; board of directors.
The pointing of a piece with reference to an imaginary vertical axis; -- distinguished from elevation. The direction is given when the plane of sight passes through the object.

Directive.def: Having power to direct; tending to direct, guide, or govern; showing the way.

Directly.def: In a direct manner; in a straight line or course.
In a straightforward way; without anything intervening; not by secondary, but by direct, means.
Without circumlocution or ambiguity; absolutely; in express terms.
Straightway; next in order; without delay; immediately.

Directness.def: The quality of being direct; straightness; straightforwardness; immediateness.

Director.def: One who, or that which, directs; one who regulates, guides, or orders; a manager or superintendent.
One of a body of persons appointed to manage the affairs of a company or corporation; as, the directors of a bank, insurance company, or railroad company.
A part of a machine or instrument which directs its motion or action.
A slender grooved instrument upon which a knife is made to slide when it is wished to limit the extent of motion of the latter, or prevent its injuring the parts beneath.

Directorate.def: The office of director; also, a body of directors taken jointly.

Directorial.def: Having the quality of a director, or authoritative guide; directive.
Pertaining to: director or directory; specifically, relating to the Directory of France under the first republic. See Directory, 3.

Directorship.def: The condition or office of a director; directorate.

Directory.def: A collection or body of directions, rules, or ordinances; esp., a book of directions for the conduct of worship; as, the Directory used by the nonconformists instead of the Prayer Book.
A book containing the names and residences of the inhabitants of any place, or of classes of them; an address book; as, a business directory.
A body of directors; board of management; especially, a committee which held executive power in France under the first republic.

Directrix.def: A line along which a point in another line moves, or which in any way governs the motion of the point and determines the position of the curve generated by it; the line along which the generatrix moves in generating a surface.
A straight line so situated with respect to a conic section that the distance of any point of the curve from it has a constant ratio to the distance of the same point from the focus.

Direful.def: Dire; dreadful; terrible; calamitous; woeful; as, a direful fiend; a direful day.

Dirempt.def: To separate by force; to tear apart.

Direption.def: The act of plundering, despoiling, or snatching away.

Direptitiously.def: With plundering violence; by violent injustice.

Dirge.def: A piece of music of a mournful character, to accompany funeral rites; a funeral hymn.

Dirige.def: A service for the dead, in the Roman Catholic Church, being the first antiphon of Matins for the dead, of which Dirige is the first word; a dirge.

Dirigent.def: The line of motion along which a describent line or surface is carried in the genesis of any plane or solid figure; a directrix.

Dirigible.def: Capable of being directed; steerable; as, a dirigible balloon.

Dirk.def: A kind of dagger or poniard; -- formerly much used by the Scottish Highlander.

Dirl.def: To thrill; to vibrate; to penetrate.

Dirt.def: Any foul of filthy substance, as excrement, mud, dust, etc.; whatever, adhering to anything, renders it foul or unclean; earth; as, a wagonload of dirt.
In placer mining, earth, gravel, etc., before washing.
To make foul of filthy; to dirty.

Dirtily.def: In a dirty manner; foully; nastily; filthily; meanly; sordidly.

Dirtiness.def: The state of being dirty; filthiness; foulness; nastiness; baseness; sordidness.

Dirty.def: Defiled with dirt; foul; nasty; filthy; not clean or pure; serving to defile; as, dirty hands; dirty water; a dirty white.
Sordid; base; groveling; as, a dirty fellow.
Sleety; gusty; stormy; as, dirty weather.
To foul; to make filthy; to soil; as, to dirty the clothes or hands.
To tarnish; to sully; to scandalize; -- said of reputation, character, etc.

Dis-.def: A prefix from the Latin, whence F. des, or sometimes de-, dis-. The Latin dis-appears as di-before b, d, g, l, m, n, r, v, becomes dif-before f, and either dis-or di- before j. It is from the same root as bis twice, and duo, E. two. See Two, and cf. Bi-, Di-, Dia-. Dis-denotes separation, a parting from, as in distribute, disconnect; hence it often has the force of a privative and negative, as in disarm, disoblige, disagree. Also intensive, as in dissever.
A prefix from Gr. di`s- twice. See Di-.

Disability.def: State of being disabled; deprivation or want of ability; absence of competent physical, intellectual, or moral power, means, fitness, and the like.
Want of legal qualification to do a thing; legal incapacity or incompetency.

Disable.def: To render unable or incapable; to destroy the force, vigor, or power of action of; to deprive of competent physical or intellectual power; to incapacitate; to disqualify; to make incompetent or unfit for service; to impair.
To deprive of legal right or qualification; to render legally incapable.
To deprive of that which gives value or estimation; to declare lacking in competency; to disparage; to undervalue.

Disabuse.def: To set free from mistakes; to undeceive; to disengage from fallacy or deception; to set right.

Disaccommodate.def: To put to inconvenience; to incommode.

Disaccommodation.def: A state of being unaccommodated or unsuited.

Disaccustom.def: To destroy the force of habit in; to wean from a custom.

Disacknowledge.def: To refuse to acknowledge; to deny; to disown.

Disacquaint.def: To render unacquainted; to make unfamiliar.

Disacquaintance.def: Neglect of disuse of familiarity, or familiar acquaintance.

Disacryl.def: A white amorphous substance obtained as a polymeric modification of acrolein.

Disadvance.def: To draw back, or cause to draw back.

Disadvantage.def: Deprivation of advantage; unfavorable or prejudicial quality, condition, circumstance, or the like; that which hinders success, or causes loss or injury.
Loss; detriment; hindrance; prejudice to interest, fame, credit, profit, or other good.
To injure the interest of; to be detrimental to.

Disadvantageous.def: Attended with disadvantage; unfavorable to success or prosperity; inconvenient; prejudicial; -- opposed to advantageous; as, the situation of an army is disadvantageous for attack or defense.

Disadvise.def: To advise against; to dissuade from.

Disaffect.def: To alienate or diminish the affection of; to make unfriendly or less friendly; to fill with discontent and unfriendliness.
To disturb the functions of; to disorder.
To lack affection for; to be alienated from, or indisposed toward; to dislike.

Disaffected.def: Alienated in feeling; not wholly loyal.

Disaffection.def: State of being disaffected; alienation or want of affection or good will, esp. toward those in authority; unfriendliness; dislike.

Disaffectionate.def: Not disposed to affection; unfriendly; disaffected.

Disaffirm.def: To assert the contrary of; to contradict; to deny; -- said of that which has been asserted.
To refuse to confirm; to annul, as a judicial decision, by a contrary judgment of a superior tribunal.

Disaffirmance.def: The act of disaffirming; denial; negation.
Overthrow or annulment by the decision of a superior tribunal; as, disaffirmance of judgment.

Disaffirmation.def: The act of disaffirming; negation; refutation.

Disafforest.def: To reduce from the privileges of a forest to the state of common ground; to exempt from forest laws.

Disaggregate.def: To destroy the aggregation of; to separate into component parts, as an aggregate mass.

Disaggregation.def: The separation of an aggregate body into its component parts.

Disagree.def: To fail to accord; not to agree; to lack harmony; to differ; to be unlike; to be at variance.
To differ in opinion; to hold discordant views; to be at controversy; to quarrel.
To be unsuited; to have unfitness; as, medicine sometimes disagrees with the patient; food often disagrees with the stomach or the taste.

Disagreeable.def: Not agreeable, conformable, or congruous; contrary; unsuitable.
Exciting repugnance; offensive to the feelings or senses; displeasing; unpleasant.

Disagreeableness.def: The state or quality of being; disagreeable; unpleasantness.

Disagreeably.def: In a disagreeable manner; unsuitably; offensively.

Disagreement.def: The state of disagreeing; a being at variance; dissimilitude; diversity.
A falling out, or controversy; difference.

Disallow.def: To refuse to allow; to deny the force or validity of; to disown and reject; as, the judge disallowed the executor's charge.

Disallowable.def: Not allowable; not to be suffered.

Disallowance.def: The act of disallowing; refusal to admit or permit; rejection.

Disally.def: To part, as an alliance; to sunder.

Disanchor.def: To raise the anchor of, as a ship; to weigh anchor.

Disanimate.def: To deprive of spirit; to dishearten.

Disanimation.def: The state of being disanimated or discouraged; depression of spirits.

Disannex.def: To disunite; to undo or repeal the annexation of.

Disannul.def: To annul completely; to render void or of no effect.

Disanoint.def: To invalidate the consecration of; as, to disanoint a king.

Disapparel.def: To disrobe; to strip of apparel; to make naked.

Disappear.def: To cease to appear or to be perceived; to pass from view, gradually or suddenly; to vanish; to be no longer seen; as, darkness disappears at the approach of light; a ship disappears as she sails from port.
To cease to be or exist; as, the epidemic has disappeared.

Disappearance.def: The act of disappearing; cessation of appearance; removal from sight; vanishing.

Disappendency.def: A detachment or separation from a former connection.

Disappendent.def: Freed from a former connection or dependence; disconnected.

Disappoint.def: To defeat of expectation or hope; to hinder from the attainment of that which was expected, hoped, or desired; to balk; as, a man is disappointed of his hopes or expectations, or his hopes, desires, intentions, expectations, or plans are disappointed; a bad season disappoints the farmer of his crops; a defeat disappoints an enemy of his spoil.
To frustrate; to fail; to hinder of result.

Disappointed.def: Defeated of expectation or hope; balked; as, a disappointed person or hope.

Disappointment.def: The act of disappointing, or the state of being disappointed; defeat or failure of expectation or hope; miscarriage of design or plan; frustration.

Disapprobation.def: The act of disapproving; mental condemnation of what is judged wrong, unsuitable, or inexpedient; feeling of censure.

Disappropriate.def: Severed from the appropriation or possession of a spiritual corporation.
To release from individual ownership or possession.
To sever from appropriation or possession a spiritual corporation.

Disapprove.def: To pass unfavorable judgment upon; to condemn by an act of the judgment; to regard as wrong, unsuitable, or inexpedient; to censure; as, to disapprove the conduct of others.
To refuse official approbation to; to disallow; to decline to sanction; as, the sentence of the court-martial was disapproved by the commander in chief.

Disarm.def: To deprive of arms; to take away the weapons of; to deprive of the means of attack or defense; to render defenseless.
To deprive of the means or the disposition to harm; to render harmless or innocuous; as, to disarm a man's wrath.

Disarmature.def: The act of divesting of armature.

Disarmed.def: Deprived of claws, and teeth or beaks.

Disarrange.def: To unsettle or disturb the order or due arrangement of; to throw out of order.

Disarrangement.def: The act of disarranging, or the state of being disarranged; confusion; disorder.

Disarray.def: To throw into disorder; to break the array of.
To take off the dress of; to unrobe.
Want of array or regular order; disorder; confusion.

Disarticulate.def: To sunder; to separate, as joints.

Disarticulator.def: One who disarticulates and prepares skeletons.

Disassimilation.def: The decomposition of complex substances, within the organism, into simpler ones suitable only for excretion, with evolution of energy, -- a normal nutritional process the reverse of assimilation; downward metabolism.

Disassimilative.def: Having power to disassimilate; of the nature of disassimilation.

Disassociate.def: To disconnect from things associated; to disunite; to dissociate.

Disaster.def: An unpropitious or baleful aspect of a planet or star; malevolent influence of a heavenly body; hence, an ill portent.
An adverse or unfortunate event, esp. a sudden and extraordinary misfortune; a calamity; a serious mishap.
To blast by the influence of a baleful star.
To bring harm upon; to injure.

Disastrous.def: Full of unpropitious stellar influences; unpropitious; ill-boding.
Attended with suffering or disaster; very unfortunate; calamitous; ill-fated; as, a disastrous day; a disastrous termination of an undertaking.

Disauthorize.def: To deprive of credit or authority; to discredit.

Disavaunce.def: To retard; to repel; to do damage to.

Disavow.def: To refuse strongly and solemnly to own or acknowledge; to deny responsibility for, approbation of, and the like; to disclaim; to disown; as, he was charged with embezzlement, but he disavows the crime.
To deny; to show the contrary of; to disprove.

Disavowal.def: The act of disavowing, disclaiming, or disowning; rejection and denial.

Disband.def: To loose the bands of; to set free; to disunite; to scatter; to disperse; to break up the organization of; especially, to dismiss from military service; as, to disband an army.
To become separated, broken up, dissolved, or scattered; especially, to quit military service by breaking up organization.

Disbar.def: To expel from the bar, or the legal profession; to deprive (an attorney, barrister, or counselor) of his status and privileges as such.

Disbark.def: To strip of bark; to bark.

Disbelief.def: The act of disbelieving;; a state of the mind in which one is fully persuaded that an opinion, assertion, or doctrine is not true; refusal of assent, credit, or credence; denial of belief.

Disbelieve.def: Not to believe; to refuse belief or credence to; to hold not to be true or actual.

Disbeliever.def: One who disbelieves, or refuses belief; an unbeliever. Specifically, one who does not believe the Christian religion.

Disbench.def: To drive from a bench or seat.
To deprive (a bencher) of his privileges.

Disboscation.def: Converting forest land into cleared or arable land; removal of a forest.

Disbranch.def: To divest of a branch or branches; to tear off.

Disbud.def: To deprive of buds or shoots, as for training, or economizing the vital strength of a tree.

Disburden.def: To rid of a burden; to free from a load borne or from something oppressive; to unload; to disencumber; to relieve.
To relieve one's self of a burden; to ease the mind.

Disburgeon.def: To strip of burgeons or buds; to disbud.

Disburse.def: To pay out; to expend; -- usually from a public fund or treasury.

Disbursement.def: The act of disbursing or paying out.
That which is disbursed or paid out; as, the annual disbursements exceed the income.

Disburthen.def: To disburden; to relieve of a load.

Disc.def: A circular structure either in plants or animals; as, a blood disc, a germinal disc, etc.  Same as Disk.

Discal.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, a disk; as, discal cells.

Discalceate.def: To pull off shoes or sandals from.

Discalceated.def: Deprived off shoes or sandals; unshod; discalced.

Discalced.def: Unshod; barefooted; -- in distinction from calced.

Discalceation.def: The act of pulling off the shoes or sandals.

Discandy.def: To melt; to dissolve; to thaw.

Discapacitate.def: To deprive of capacity; to incapacitate.

Discard.def: To throw out of one's hand, as superfluous cards; to lay aside (a card or cards).
To cast off as useless or as no longer of service; to dismiss from employment, confidence, or favor; to discharge; to turn away.
To put or thrust away; to reject.
The act of discarding; also, the card or cards discarded.

Discede.def: To yield or give up; to depart.

Discern.def: To see and identify by noting a difference or differences; to note the distinctive character of; to discriminate; to distinguish.
To see by the eye or by the understanding; to perceive and recognize; as, to discern a difference.
To see or understand the difference; to make distinction; as, to discern between good and evil, truth and falsehood.

Discerner.def: One who, or that which, discerns, distinguishes, perceives, or judges; as, a discerner of truth, of right and wrong.

Discernible.def: Capable of being discerned by the eye or the understanding; as, a star is discernible by the eye; the identity of difference of ideas is discernible by the understanding.

Discernibly.def: In a manner to be discerned; perceptibly; visibly.

Discerningly.def: In a discerning manner; with judgment; judiciously; acutely.

Discernment.def: The power or faculty of the mind by which it distinguishes one thing from another; power of viewing differences in objects, and their relations and tendencies; penetrative and discriminate mental vision; acuteness; sagacity; insight; as, the errors of youth often proceed from the want of discernment.

Discerp.def: To tear in pieces; to rend.

Discerptibility.def: Capability or liableness to be discerped.

Discerption.def: The act of pulling to pieces, or of separating the parts.

Discerptive.def: Tending to separate or disunite parts.

Discharge.def: To relieve of a charge, load, or burden; to empty of a load or cargo; to unburden; to unload; as, to discharge a vessel.

To free of the missile with which anything is charged or loaded; to let go the charge of; as, to discharge a bow, catapult, etc.; especially, said of firearms, -- to fire off; to shoot off; also, to relieve from a state of tension, as a Leyden jar.
To of something weighing upon or impeding over one, as a debt, claim, obligation, responsibility, accusation, etc.; to absolve; to acquit; to clear.
To relieve of an office or employment; to send away from service; to dismiss.
To release legally from confinement; to set at liberty; as, to discharge a prisoner.
To put forth, or remove, as a charge or burden; to take out, as that with which anything is loaded or filled; as, to discharge a cargo.
To let fly, as a missile; to shoot.
To set aside; to annul; to dismiss.
To throw off the obligation of, as a duty or debt; to relieve one's self of, by fulfilling conditions, performing duty, trust, and the like; hence, to perform or execute, as an office, or part.
To send away (a creditor) satisfied by payment; to pay one's debt or obligation to.
To give forth; to emit or send out; as, a pipe discharges water; to let fly; to give expression to; to utter; as, to discharge a horrible oath.
To prohibit; to forbid.
To throw off or deliver a load, charge, or burden; to unload; to emit or give vent to fluid or other contents; as, the water pipe discharges freely.
The act of discharging; the act of relieving of a charge or load; removal of a load or burden; unloading; as, the discharge of a ship; discharge of a cargo.
Firing off; explosive removal of a charge; explosion; letting off; as, a discharge of arrows, of artillery.
Act of relieving of something which oppresses or weighs upon one, as an obligation, liability, debt, accusation, etc.; acquittance; as, the discharge of a debtor.
Act of removing, or getting rid of, an obligation, liability, etc.; fulfillment, as by the payment of a debt, or the performance of a trust or duty.
Release or dismissal from an office, employment, etc.; dismission; as, the discharge of a workman by his employer.
Legal release from confinement; liberation; as, the discharge of a prisoner.
The state of being discharged or relieved of a debt, obligation, office, and the like; acquittal.
That which discharges or releases from an obligation, liability, penalty, etc., as a price of ransom, a legal document.
A flowing or issuing out; emission; vent; evacuation; also, that which is discharged or emitted; as, a rapid discharge of water from the pipe.

Discharger.def: One who, or that which, discharges. Specifically, in electricity, an instrument for discharging a Leyden jar, or electrical battery, by making a connection between the two surfaces; a discharging rod.

Dischurch.def: To deprive of status as a church, or of membership in a church.

Discide.def: To divide; to cleave in two.

Disciflorous.def: Bearing the stamens on a discoid outgrowth of the receptacle; -- said of a subclass of plants.  Cf. Calycifloral.

Discina.def: A genus of Branchiopoda, having a disklike shell, attached by one valve, which is perforated by the peduncle.

Disciple.def: One who receives instruction from another; a scholar; a learner; especially, a follower who has learned to believe in the truth of the doctrine of his teacher; an adherent in doctrine; as, the disciples of Plato; the disciples of our Savior.
To make disciples of; to convert to doctrines or principles.

Discipleship.def: The state of being a disciple or follower in doctrines and precepts.

Disciplinable.def: Capable of being disciplined or improved by instruction and training.
Liable or deserving to be disciplined; subject to disciplinary punishment; as, a disciplinable offense.

Disciplinableness.def: The quality of being improvable by discipline.

Disciplinarian.def: One who disciplines; one who excels in training, especially with training, especially with regard to order and obedience; one who enforces rigid discipline; a stickler for the observance of rules and methods of training; as, he is a better disciplinarian than scholar.
A Puritan or Presbyterian; -- because of rigid adherence to religious or church discipline.

Disciplinary.def: Pertaining to discipline; intended for discipline; corrective; belonging to a course of training.

Discipline.def: The treatment suited to a disciple or learner; education; development of the faculties by instruction and exercise; training, whether physical, mental, or moral.
Training to act in accordance with established rules; accustoming to systematic and regular action; drill.
Subjection to rule; submissiveness to order and control; habit of obedience.
Severe training, corrective of faults; instruction by means of misfortune, suffering, punishment, etc.
Correction; chastisement; punishment inflicted by way of correction and training.
The subject matter of instruction; a branch of knowledge.
The enforcement of methods of correction against one guilty of ecclesiastical offenses; reformatory or penal action toward a church member.
Self-inflicted and voluntary corporal punishment, as penance, or otherwise; specifically, a penitential scourge.
A system of essential rules and duties; as, the Romish or Anglican discipline.
To educate; to develop by instruction and exercise; to train.

To accustom to regular and systematic action; to bring under control so as to act systematically; to train to act together under orders; to teach subordination to; to form a habit of obedience in; to drill.
To improve by corrective and penal methods; to chastise; to correct.
To inflict ecclesiastical censures and penalties upon.

Disclaim.def: To renounce all claim to deny; ownership of, or responsibility for; to disown; to disavow; to reject.
To deny, as a claim; to refuse.
To relinquish or deny having a claim; to disavow another's claim; to decline accepting, as an estate, interest, or office.
To disavow or renounce all part, claim, or share.

Disclaimer.def: One who disclaims, disowns, or renounces.
A denial, disavowal, or renunciation, as of a title, claim, interest, estate, or trust; relinquishment or waiver of an interest or estate.
A public disavowal, as of pretensions, claims, opinions, and the like.

Disclaunder.def: To injure one's good name; to slander.

Discloak.def: To take off a cloak from; to uncloak.

Disclose.def: To unclose; to open; -- applied esp. to eggs in the sense of to hatch.
To remove a cover or envelope from;; to set free from inclosure; to uncover.
To lay open or expose to view; to cause to appear; to bring to light; to reveal.
To make known, as that which has been kept secret or hidden; to reveal; to expose; as, events have disclosed his designs.

Disclosed.def: Represented with wings expanded; -- applied to doves and other birds not of prey.

Disclosure.def: The act of disclosing, uncovering, or revealing; bringing to light; exposure.
That which is disclosed or revealed.

Discoast.def: To depart; to quit the coast (that is, the side or border) of anything; to be separated.

Discoblastic.def: Applied to a form of egg cleavage seen in osseous fishes, which occurs only in a small disk that separates from the rest of the egg.

Discobolus.def: A statue of an athlete holding the discus, or about to throw it.

Discodactylia.def: A division of amphibians having suctorial disks on the toes, as the tree frogs.

Discodactylous.def: Having sucking disks on the toes, as the tree frogs.

Discoid.def: Having the form of a disk, as those univalve shells which have the whorls in one plane, so as to form a disk, as the pearly nautilus.
Anything having the form of a discus or disk; particularly, a discoid shell.

Discolith.def: One of a species of coccoliths, having an oval discoidal body, with a thick strongly refracting rim, and a thinner central portion. One of them measures about / of an inch in its longest diameter.

Discolor.def: To alter the natural hue or color of; to change to a different color; to stain; to tinge; as, a drop of wine will discolor water; silver is discolored by sea water.
To alter the true complexion or appearance of; to put a false hue upon.

Discoloration.def: The act of discoloring, or the state of being discolored; alteration of hue or appearance.

Discomfit.def: To scatter in fight; to put to rout; to defeat.
To break up and frustrate the plans of; to balk/ to throw into perplexity and dejection; to disconcert.

Discomfiture.def: The act of discomfiting, or the state of being discomfited; rout; overthrow; defeat; frustration; confusion and dejection.

Discomfort.def: To destroy or disturb the comfort of; to deprive o/ quiet enjoyment; to make uneasy; to pain; as, a smoky chimney discomforts a family.
Want of comfort; uneasiness, mental or physical; disturbance of peace; inquietude; pain; distress; sorrow.

Discomfortable.def: Causing discomfort; occasioning uneasiness; making sad.

Discommend.def: To mention with disapprobation; to blame; to disapprove.
To expose to censure or ill favor; to put out of the good graces of any one.

Discommission.def: To deprive of a commission or trust.

Discommode.def: To put inconvenience; to incommode; to trouble.

Discommon.def: To deprive of the right of common.
To deprive of commonable quality, as lands, by inclosing or appropriating.

Discommunity.def: A lack of common possessions, properties, or relationship.

Discompany.def: To free from company; to dissociate.

Discomplexion.def: To change the complexion or hue of.

Discompliance.def: Failure or refusal to comply; noncompliance.

Discompose.def: To disarrange; to interfere with; to disturb; to disorder; to unsettle; to break up.
To throw into disorder; to ruffle; to destroy the composure or equanimity; to agitate.
To put out of place or service; to discharge; to displace.

Discomposure.def: The state of being discomposed; disturbance; disorder; agitation; perturbation.

Disconcert.def: To break up the harmonious progress of; to throw into disorder or confusion; as, the emperor disconcerted the plans of his enemy.
To confuse the faculties of; to disturb the composure of; to discompose; to abash.

Disconcertion.def: The act of disconcerting, or state of being disconcerted; discomposure; perturbation.

Disconformity.def: Want of conformity or correspondence; inconsistency; disagreement.

Disconnect.def: To dissolve the union or connection of; to disunite; to sever; to separate; to disperse.

Disconnection.def: The act of disconnecting, or state of being disconnected; separation; want of union.

Disconsecrate.def: To deprive of consecration or sacredness.

Discosent.def: To differ; to disagree; to dissent.

Disconsolate.def: Destitute of consolation; deeply dejected and dispirited; hopelessly sad; comfortless; filled with grief; as, a bereaved and disconsolate parent.
Inspiring dejection; saddening; cheerless; as, the disconsolate darkness of the winter nights.

Discontent.def: To deprive of content; to make uneasy; to dissatisfy.
Want of content; uneasiness and inquietude of mind; dissatisfaction; disquiet.

Discontentment.def: The state of being discontented; uneasiness; inquietude.

Discontinuance.def: The act of discontinuing, or the state of being discontinued; want of continued connection or continuity; breaking off; cessation; interruption; as, a discontinuance of conversation or intercourse; discontinuance of a highway or of travel.

A breaking off or interruption of an estate, which happened when an alienation was made by a tenant in tail, or other tenant, seized in right of another, of a larger estate than the tenant was entitled to, whereby the party ousted or injured was driven to his real action, and could not enter. This effect of such alienation is now obviated by statute in both England and the United States.
The termination of an action in practice by the voluntary act of the plaintiff; an entry on the record that the plaintiff discontinues his action.

That technical interruption of the proceedings in pleading in an action, which follows where a defendant does not answer the whole of the plaintiff's declaration, and the plaintiff omits to take judgment for the part unanswered.

Discontinuation.def: Breach or interruption of continuity; separation of parts in a connected series; discontinuance.

Discontinue.def: To interrupt the continuance of; to intermit, as a practice or habit; to put an end to; to cause to cease; to cease using, to stop; to leave off.
To lose continuity or cohesion of parts; to be disrupted or broken off.
To be separated or severed; to part.

Discontinuee.def: One whose possession of an estate is broken off, or discontinued; one whose estate is subject to discontinuance.

Discontinuer.def: One who discontinues, or breaks off or away from; an absentee.

Discontinuity.def: Want of continuity or cohesion; disunion of parts.

Discontinuor.def: One who deprives another of the possession of an estate by discontinuance. See Discontinuance, 2.

Discontinuous.def: Exhibiting a dissolution of continuity; gaping.

Disconvenient.def: Not convenient or congruous; unsuitable; ill-adapted.

Discophora.def: A division of acalephs or jellyfishes, including most of the large disklike species.

Discord.def: Want of concord or agreement; absence of unity or harmony in sentiment or action; variance leading to contention and strife; disagreement; -- applied to persons or to things, and to thoughts, feelings, or purposes.

Union of musical sounds which strikes the ear harshly or disagreeably, owing to the incommensurability of the vibrations which they produce; want of musical concord or harmony; a chord demanding resolution into a concord.
To disagree; to be discordant; to jar; to clash; not to suit.

Discordable.def: That may produce discord; disagreeing; discordant.

Discordancy.def: State or quality of being discordant; disagreement; inconsistency.

Discordant.def: Disagreeing; incongruous; being at variance; clashing; opposing; not harmonious.
Dissonant; not in harmony or musical concord; harsh; jarring; as, discordant notes or sounds.
Said of strata which lack conformity in direction of bedding, either as in unconformability, or as caused by a fault.

Discorporate.def: Deprived of the privileges or form of a body corporate.

Discount.def: To deduct from an account, debt, charge, and the like; to make an abatement of; as, merchants sometimes discount five or six per cent for prompt payment of bills.
To lend money upon, deducting the discount or allowance for interest; as, the banks discount notes and bills of exchange.
To take into consideration beforehand; to anticipate and form conclusions concerning (an event).
To leave out of account; to take no notice of.
To lend, or make a practice of lending, money, abating the discount; as, the discount for sixty or ninety days.
A counting off or deduction made from a gross sum on any account whatever; an allowance upon an account, debt, demand, price asked, and the like; something taken or deducted.
A deduction made for interest, in advancing money upon, or purchasing, a bill or note not due; payment in advance of interest upon money.
The rate of interest charged in discounting.

Discountable.def: Capable of being, or suitable to be, discounted; as, certain forms are necessary to render notes discountable at a bank.

Discountenance.def: To ruffle or discompose the countenance of; to put of countenance; to put to shame; to abash.
To refuse to countenance, or give the support of one's approval to; to give one's influence against; to restrain by cold treatment; to discourage.
Unfavorable aspect; unfriendly regard; cold treatment; disapprobation; whatever tends to check or discourage.

Discountenancer.def: One who discountenances; one who disfavors.

Discounter.def: One who discounts; a discount broker.

Discourage.def: To extinguish the courage of; to dishearten; to depress the spirits of; to deprive of confidence; to deject; -- the opposite of encourage; as, he was discouraged in his undertaking; he need not be discouraged from a like attempt.
To dishearten one with respect to; to discountenance; to seek to check by disfavoring; to deter one from; as, they discouraged his efforts.

Discourageable.def: Capable of being discouraged; easily disheartened.

Discouragement.def: The act of discouraging, or the state of being discouraged; depression or weakening of confidence; dejection.

That which discourages; that which deters, or tends to deter, from an undertaking, or from the prosecution of anything; a determent; as, the revolution was commenced under every possible discouragement.

Discourse.def: The power of the mind to reason or infer by running, as it were, from one fact or reason to another, and deriving a conclusion; an exercise or act of this power; reasoning; range of reasoning faculty.
The art and manner of speaking and conversing.
Consecutive speech, either written or unwritten, on a given line of thought; speech; treatise; dissertation; sermon, etc.; as, the preacher gave us a long discourse on duty.
To exercise reason; to employ the mind in judging and inferring; to reason.
To express one's self in oral discourse; to expose one's views; to talk in a continuous or formal manner; to hold forth; to speak; to converse.
To treat of something in writing and formally.
To treat of; to expose or set forth in language.
To utter or give forth; to speak.
To talk to; to confer with.

Discourser.def: One who discourse; a narrator; a speaker; an haranguer.
The writer of a treatise or dissertation.

Discoursive.def: Reasoning; characterized by reasoning; passing from premises to consequences; discursive.
Inclined to converse; conversable; communicative; as, a discoursive man.
The state or quality of being discoursive or able to reason.

Discourteous.def: Uncivil; rude; wanting in courtesy or good manners; uncourteous.

Discourtesy.def: Rudeness of behavior or language; ill manners; manifestation of disrespect; incivility.

Discover.def: To disclose; to lay open to view; to make visible; to reveal; to make known; to show (what has been secret, unseen, or unknown).
To obtain for the first time sight or knowledge of, as of a thing existing already, but not perceived or known; to find; to ascertain; to espy; to detect.
To manifest without design; to show.
To discover or show one's self.

Discoverable.def: Capable of being discovered, found out, or perceived; as, many minute animals are discoverable only by the help of the microscope; truths discoverable by human industry.

Discoverer.def: One who discovers; one who first comes to the knowledge of something; one who discovers an unknown country, or a new principle, truth, or fact.

Discovert.def: Not covert; not within the bonds of matrimony; unmarried; -- applied either to a woman who has never married or to a widow.

Discoverture.def: A state of being released from coverture; freedom of a woman from the coverture of a husband.

Discovery.def: The action of discovering; exposure to view; laying open; showing; as, the discovery of a plot.
A making known; revelation; disclosure; as, a bankrupt is bound to make a full discovery of his assets.
Finding out or ascertaining something previously unknown or unrecognized; as, Harvey's discovery of the circulation of the blood.
That which is discovered; a thing found out, or for the first time ascertained or recognized; as, the properties of the magnet were an important discovery.

Discredit.def: The act of discrediting or disbelieving, or the state of being discredited or disbelieved; as, later accounts have brought the story into discredit.
Hence, some degree of dishonor or disesteem; ill repute; reproach; -- applied to persons or things.
To refuse credence to; not to accept as true; to disbelieve; as, the report is discredited.
To deprive of credibility; to destroy confidence or trust in; to cause disbelief in the accuracy or authority of.
To deprive of credit or good repute; to bring reproach upon; to make less reputable; to disgrace.

Discreditable.def: Not creditable; injurious to reputation; disgraceful; disreputable.

Discreet.def: Possessed of discernment, especially in avoiding error or evil, and in the adaptation of means to ends; prudent; sagacious; judicious; not rash or heedless; cautious.

Discrepancy.def: The state or quality of being discrepant; disagreement; variance; discordance; dissimilarity; contrariety.

Discrepant.def: Discordant; at variance; disagreeing; contrary; different.

Discrete.def: Disjunctive; containing a disjunctive or discretive clause; as, "I resign my life, but not my honor," is a discrete proposition.
Separate; not coalescent; -- said of things usually coalescent.

Discretion.def: The quality of being discreet; wise conduct and management; cautious discernment, especially as to matters of propriety and self-control; prudence; circumspection; wariness.
Freedom to act according to one's own judgment; unrestrained exercise of choice or will.

Discretionary.def: Left to discretion; unrestrained except by discretion or judgment; as, an ambassador with discretionary powers.

Discretionarily.def: At discretion; according to one's discretion or judgment.

Discriminal.def: In palmistry, applied to the line which marks the separation between the hand and the arm.

Discriminant.def: The eliminant of the n partial differentials of any homogenous function of n variables. See Eliminant.

Discriminate.def: Having the difference marked; distinguished by certain tokens.
To set apart as being different; to mark as different; to separate from another by discerning differences; to distinguish.
To make a difference or distinction; to distinguish accurately; as, in judging of evidence, we should be careful to discriminate between probability and slight presumption.
To impose unequal tariffs for substantially the same service.

Discriminateness.def: The state of being discriminated; distinctness.

Discrimination.def: The act of discriminating, distinguishing, or noting and marking differences.
The state of being discriminated, distinguished, or set apart.
The arbitrary imposition of unequal tariffs for substantially the same service.
The quality of being discriminating; faculty of nicely distinguishing; acute discernment; as, to show great discrimination in the choice of means.
That which discriminates; mark of distinction.

Discriminative.def: Marking a difference; distinguishing; distinctive; characteristic.

Discubitory.def: Leaning; fitted for a reclining posture.

Disculpate.def: To free from blame or the imputation of a fault; to exculpate.

Discumbency.def: The act of reclining at table according to the manner of the ancients at their meals.

Discumber.def: To free from that which cumbers or impedes; to disencumber.

Discure.def: To discover; to reveal; to discoure.

Discurrent.def: Not current or free to circulate; not in use.

Discursion.def: The act of discoursing or reasoning; range, as from thought to thought.

Discursive.def: Passing from one thing to another; ranging over a wide field; roving; digressive; desultory.
Reasoning; proceeding from one ground to another, as in reasoning; argumentative.

Discus.def: A quoit; a circular plate of some heavy material intended to be pitched or hurled as a trial of strength and skill.

Discuss.def: To break to pieces; to shatter.
To break up; to disperse; to scatter; to dissipate; to drive away; -- said especially of tumors.
To shake; to put away; to finish.
To examine in detail or by disputation; to reason upon by presenting favorable and adverse considerations; to debate; to sift; to investigate; to ventilate.
To deal with, in eating or drinking.
To examine or search thoroughly; to exhaust a remedy against, as against a principal debtor before proceeding against the surety.

Discusser.def: One who discusses; one who sifts or examines.

Discussion.def: The act or process of discussing by breaking up, or dispersing, as a tumor, or the like.
The act of discussing or exchanging reasons; examination by argument; debate; disputation; agitation.

Discussive.def: Able or tending to discuss or disperse tumors or coagulated matter.
A medicine that discusses or disperses morbid humors; a discutient.

Discutient.def: Serving to disperse morbid matter; discussive; as, a discutient application.
An agent (as a medicinal application) which serves to disperse morbid matter.

Disdain.def: A feeling of contempt and aversion; the regarding anything as unworthy of or beneath one; scorn.
That which is worthy to be disdained or regarded with contempt and aversion.
The state of being despised; shame.
To think unworthy; to deem unsuitable or unbecoming; as, to disdain to do a mean act.
To reject as unworthy of one's self, or as not deserving one's notice; to look with scorn upon; to scorn, as base acts, character, etc.
To be filled with scorn; to feel contemptuous anger; to be haughty.

Disdainful.def: Full of disdain; expressing disdain; scornful; contemptuous; haughty.

Disdeify.def: To divest or deprive of deity or of a deific rank or condition.

Disdiaclast.def: One of the dark particles forming the doubly refracting disks of muscle fibers.

Disdiapason.def: An interval of two octaves, or a fifteenth; -- called also bisdiapason.

Disease.def: Lack of ease; uneasiness; trouble; vexation; disquiet.

An alteration in the state of the body or of some of its organs, interrupting or disturbing the performance of the vital functions, and causing or threatening pain and weakness; malady; affection; illness; sickness; disorder; -- applied figuratively to the mind, to the moral character and habits, to institutions, the state, etc.
To deprive of ease; to disquiet; to trouble; to distress.
To derange the vital functions of; to afflict with disease or sickness; to disorder; -- used almost exclusively in the participle diseased.

Diseasedness.def: The state of being diseased; a morbid state; sickness.

Diseaseful.def: Abounding with disease; producing diseases; as, a diseaseful climate.

Diseasefulness.def: The quality of being diseaseful; trouble; trial.

Disedge.def: To deprive of an edge; to blunt; to dull.

Disedify.def: To fail of edifying; to injure.

Diselder.def: To deprive of an elder or elders, or of the office of an elder.

Diselenide.def: A selenide containing two atoms of selenium in each molecule.

Disembark.def: To remove from on board a vessel; to put on shore; to land; to debark; as, the general disembarked the troops.
To go ashore out of a ship or boat; to leave a ship; to debark.

Disembarrass.def: To free from embarrassment, or perplexity; to clear; to extricate.

Disembarrassment.def: Freedom or relief from impediment or perplexity.

Disembellish.def: To deprive of embellishment; to disadorn.

Disembodied.def: Divested of a body; ceased to be corporal; incorporeal.

Disembodiment.def: The act of disembodying, or the state of being disembodied.

Disembody.def: To divest of the body or corporeal existence.
To disarm and disband, as a body of soldiers.

Disembogue.def: To pour out or discharge at the mouth, as a stream; to vent; to discharge into an ocean, a lake, etc.
To become discharged; to flow out; to find vent; to pour out contents.

Disembowel.def: To take or let out the bowels or interior parts of; to eviscerate.
To take or draw from the body, as the web of a spider.

Disembowelment.def: The act of disemboweling, or state of being disemboweled; evisceration.

Disembowered.def: Deprived of, or removed from, a bower.

Disembrangle.def: To free from wrangling or litigation.

Disembroil.def: To disentangle; to free from perplexity; to extricate from confusion.

Disemployment.def: The state of being disemployed, or deprived of employment.

Disempower.def: To deprive of power; to divest of strength.

Disenamor.def: To free from the captivity of love.

Disenchant.def: To free from enchantment; to deliver from the power of charms or spells; to free from fascination or delusion.

Disenchanter.def: One who, or that which, disenchants.

Disenchantment.def: The act of disenchanting, or state of being disenchanted.

Disencharm.def: To free from the influence of a charm or spell; to disenchant.

Disencumber.def: To free from encumbrance, or from anything which clogs, impedes, or obstructs; to disburden.

Disencumbrance.def: Freedom or deliverance from encumbrance, or anything burdensome or troublesome.

Disendow.def: To deprive of an endowment, as a church.

Disendowment.def: The act of depriving of an endowment or endowments.

Disenfranchise.def: To disfranchise; to deprive of the rights of a citizen.

Disengage.def: To release from that with which anything is engaged, engrossed, involved, or entangled; to extricate; to detach; to set free; to liberate; to clear; as, to disengage one from a party, from broils and controversies, from an oath, promise, or occupation; to disengage the affections a favorite pursuit, the mind from study.
To release one's self; to become detached; to free one's self.

Disengaged.def: Not engaged; free from engagement; at leisure; free from occupation or care; vacant.

Disengagement.def: The act of disengaging or setting free, or the state of being disengaged.

Disennoble.def: To deprive of that which ennobles; to degrade.

Disenroll.def: To erase from a roll or list.

Disenshrouded.def: Freed from a shroudlike covering; unveiled.

Disenslave.def: To free from bondage or slavery; to disenthrall.

Disentangle.def: To free from entanglement; to release from a condition of being intricately and confusedly involved or interlaced; to reduce to orderly arrangement; to straighten out; as, to disentangle a skein of yarn.
To extricate from complication and perplexity; disengage from embarrassing connection or intermixture; to disembroil; to set free; to separate.

Disentanglement.def: The act of disentangling or clearing from difficulties.

Disenthrall.def: To release from thralldom or slavery; to give freedom to; to disinthrall.

Disenthrone.def: To dethrone; to depose from sovereign authority.

Disentitle.def: To deprive of title or claim.

Disentomb.def: To take out from a tomb; a disinter.

Disentrail.def: To disembowel; to let out or draw forth, as the entrails.

Disentrance.def: To awaken from a trance or an enchantment.

Disentwine.def: To free from being entwined or twisted.

Disespouse.def: To release from espousal or plighted faith.

Disestablish.def: To unsettle; to break up (anything established); to deprive, as a church, of its connection with the state.

Disestablishment.def: The act or process of unsettling or breaking up that which has been established; specifically, the withdrawal of the support of the state from an established church; as, the disestablishment and disendowment of the Irish Church by Act of Parliament.

Disesteem.def: Want of esteem; low estimation, inclining to dislike; disfavor; disrepute.
To feel an absence of esteem for; to regard with disfavor or slight contempt; to slight.
To deprive of esteem; to bring into disrepute; to cause to be regarded with disfavor.

Disexercise.def: To deprive of exercise; to leave untrained.

Disfavor.def: Want of favor of favorable regard; disesteem; disregard.
The state of not being in favor; a being under the displeasure of some one; state of unacceptableness; as, to be in disfavor at court.
To withhold or withdraw favor from; to regard with disesteem; to show disapprobation of; to discountenance.
To injure the form or looks of.

Disfeature.def: To deprive of features; to mar the features of.

Disfellowship.def: To exclude from fellowship; to refuse intercourse with, as an associate.

Disfiguration.def: The act of disfiguring, or the state of being disfigured; defacement; deformity; disfigurement.

Disfigure.def: To mar the figure of; to render less complete, perfect, or beautiful in appearance; to deface; to deform.

Disfigurement.def: Act of disfiguring, or state of being disfigured; deformity.
That which disfigures; a defacement; a blot.

Disflesh.def: To reduce the flesh or obesity of.

Disforest.def: To clear or deprive of forests or trees.

Disforestation.def: The act of clearing land of forests.

Disformity.def: Discordance or diversity of form; unlikeness in form.

Disfranchise.def: To deprive of a franchise or chartered right; to dispossess of the rights of a citizen, or of a particular privilege, as of voting, holding office, etc.

Disfranchisement.def: The act of disfranchising, or the state disfranchised; deprivation of privileges of citizenship or of chartered immunities.

Disfriar.def: To depose or withdraw from the condition of a friar.

Disfurnish.def: To deprive of that with which anything is furnished (furniture, equipments, etc.); to strip; to render destitute; to divest.

Disfurnishment.def: The act of disfurnishing, or the state of being disfurnished.

Disfurniture.def: The act of disfurnishing, or the state of being disfurnished.

Disgage.def: To free from a gage or pledge; to disengage.

Disgarnish.def: To divest of garniture; to disfurnish; to dismantle.

Disgavel.def: To deprive of that principal quality of gavelkind tenure by which lands descend equally among all the sons of the tenant; -- said of lands.

Disglorify.def: To deprive of glory; to treat with indignity.

Disgorge.def: To eject or discharge by the throat and mouth; to vomit; to pour forth or throw out with violence, as if from the mouth; to discharge violently or in great quantities from a confined place.
To give up unwillingly as what one has wrongfully seized and appropriated; to make restitution of; to surrender; as, he was compelled to disgorge his ill-gotten gains.
To vomit forth what anything contains; to discharge; to make restitution.

Disgorgement.def: The act of disgorging; a vomiting; that which is disgorged.

Disgospel.def: To be inconsistent with, or act contrary to, the precepts of the gospel; to pervert the gospel.

Disgrace.def: The condition of being out of favor; loss of favor, regard, or respect.
The state of being dishonored, or covered with shame; dishonor; shame; ignominy.
That which brings dishonor; cause of shame or reproach; great discredit; as, vice is a disgrace to a rational being.
An act of unkindness; a disfavor.
To put out favor; to dismiss with dishonor.
To do disfavor to; to bring reproach or shame upon; to dishonor; to treat or cover with ignominy; to lower in estimation.
To treat discourteously; to upbraid; to revile.

Disgraceful.def: Bringing disgrace; causing shame; shameful; dishonorable; unbecoming; as, profaneness is disgraceful to a man.

Disgradation.def: Degradation; a stripping of titles and honors.

Disgraduate.def: To degrade; to reduce in rank.

Disgregate.def: To disperse; to scatter; -- opposite of congregate.

Disgregation.def: The process of separation, or the condition of being separate, as of the molecules of a body.

Disgruntle.def: To dissatisfy; to disaffect; to anger.

Disguise.def: To change the guise or appearance of; especially, to conceal by an unusual dress, or one intended to mislead or deceive.
To hide by a counterfeit appearance; to cloak by a false show; to mask; as, to disguise anger; to disguise one's sentiments, character, or intentions.
To affect or change by liquor; to intoxicate.
A dress or exterior put on for purposes of concealment or of deception; as, persons doing unlawful acts in disguise are subject to heavy penalties.
Artificial language or manner assumed for deception; false appearance; counterfeit semblance or show.
Change of manner by drink; intoxication.

Disguiser.def: One who, or that which, disguises.
One who wears a disguise; an actor in a masquerade; a masker.

Disgust.def: To provoke disgust or strong distaste in; to cause (any one) loathing, as of the stomach; to excite aversion in; to offend the moral taste of; -- often with at, with, or by.

Repugnance to what is offensive; aversion or displeasure produced by something loathsome; loathing; strong distaste; -- said primarily of the sickening opposition felt for anything which offends the physical organs of taste; now rather of the analogous repugnance excited by anything extremely unpleasant to the moral taste or higher sensibilities of our nature; as, an act of cruelty may excite disgust.

Disgustful.def: Provoking disgust; offensive to the taste; exciting aversion; disgusting.

Disgusting.def: That causes disgust; sickening; offensive; revolting.

Dish.def: A vessel, as a platter, a plate, a bowl, used for serving up food at the table.
The food served in a dish; hence, any particular kind of food; as, a cold dish; a warm dish; a delicious dish. "A dish fit for the gods."
The state of being concave, or like a dish, or the degree of such concavity; as, the dish of a wheel.
A hollow place, as in a field.
A trough about 28 inches long, 4 deep, and 6 wide, in which ore is measured.
That portion of the produce of a mine which is paid to the land owner or proprietor.
To put in a dish, ready for the table.
To make concave, or depress in the middle, like a dish; as, to dish a wheel by inclining the spokes.
To frustrate; to beat; to ruin.

Dishabille.def: An undress; a loose, negligent dress; deshabille.

Dishaunt.def: To leave; to quit; to cease to haunt.

Dishcloth.def: A cloth used for washing dishes.

Dishearten.def: To discourage; to deprive of courage and hope; to depress the spirits of; to deject.

Disherison.def: The act of disheriting, or debarring from inheritance; disinhersion.
